application_protocol.name: functional_data_and_their_schematic_representation_for_process_plant
application_protocol.title: Functional data and their schematic representation for process plant
application_protocol.purpose: the exchange of functional data and their schematic representation for process plant. Functional data includes the functional design of systems, and the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.
application_protocol.keywords: application protocol, functional data, schematic representation, process plant, system

abstract.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the exchange of functional data and their schematic representation for process plant. Functional data includes the functional design of systems, and the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the functional design of systems within a process plant, and for the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.

The principal activities that take place during the life of a process plant, and the flows of information and material between them, are shown in Figure 1. The two activities, which are principally addressed by this application protocol are:

ul.li: conceptual design;
detailed design.

purpose.p: The schema for this part of ISO 10303 is specified by reference to the application module that is appropriate to the conformance class, as defined in clauses 6.1, 6.2 and 6.3.
Each module references further modules. The hierarchy of module dependencies defined by these references is shown in the tree of module dependence diagrams beginning with Figure 4.
There is a substantial overlap in scope between this part of ISO 10303 and ISO 10303-227. The overlap in scope is summarised by Figure 2.

purpose.p: With the exception of the clauses related to schematic representation, the content of this part of ISO 10303 is derived from ISO 15926-2. A subset of ISO 15926-2 has been expressed using the methodology of an ISO 10303 application protocol.

The subset has been chosen to support the exchange of process plant functional data at a particular instant during the life of a process plant. This part of ISO 10303 does not support information about the way in which data has changed during the life of a process plant.

Data defined by this part of ISO 10303 can be merged with other data within a life cycle data repository structured according to ISO 15926-2. This part of 10303 is concerned with a single life cycle stage, which can be a single design or a record of what exists at a single instant in time. A repository structured according to ISO 15926 can hold the same data but for multiple versions or a design and at multiple instants in time.

If an ARM entity within an Application Module referenced by this part of ISO 10303, corresponds to an entity in ISO 15926-2, then that correspondence is indicated by a note within the Application Module at the end of the ARM entity definition.

li.p: functional data about a physical object within a process plant;
Functional data consists of:

ul.li: the identification of a physical object;
the decomposition of a physical object into sub-assemblies or sub-systems;
connections between physical objects;
the classifications of a physical object;
the properties of a physical object.

li.p: A physical object within a process plant is one of the following:

ul.li: a system;
a individual item of equipment;
a component of a system or of an item of equipment;
a batch of process or utility material; or
a stream of process or utility material.

example.p: Crude oil is a process material.
Cooling water is a utility material.

li.p: A system within a process plant is one of the following:

ul.li: a system that handle process materials and utility materials;
an auxiliary system for an equipment item;
a process control and monitoring system;
a safety, health and environmental control and monitoring system; or
an electrical power generation, transmission and distribution systems with a process plant.

example.p: A lubricating oil system is an auxiliary system for an equipment item.
Equipment items and components within scope include:

ul.li: process equipment, such as vessels, columns, reactors, pumps, compressors, heat exchangers, boilers, furnaces, storage tanks, and their auxiliary systems;
instrumentation items, such as control and safety/relief valves, gauges, and thermocouples;
piping and pipe fittings;
safety health and environmental system hardware, such as intrusion alarms, site access controls, weigh bridges, fire alarms, building automation systems, HVAC, smoke detectors, and sniffers.

li.p: the specification of an activity carried out by or on a system within a process plant;
The specification of an activity consists of:

ul.li: the identification an activity;
the decomposition an activity into sub-activities;
the classifications of an activity;
the properties of an activity;
the involvement of systems, equipment items and components, batches and streams of material, people, and organisations in an activity.

li.p: The activities within scope are:

ul.li: the transformation of a batch or stream of material;
the transportation of a batch of material;
the change of properties of a batch or stream of material;
the change of properties, composition relationships, or connection relationships for a system or equipment item;
the storage of a batch of material.

example.p: A chemical reaction is a transformation.
A flow through a pipe or wire, or via a conveyor belt, is a transportation.
The heating of a fluid is a change of property.
The holding of a batch of liquid in a tank is a storage activity.

note.p: The link between a symbol on a schematic and a physical object or activity makes the schematic 'intelligent'. An application can use this link to support access to data about the physical object or activity by clicking on the symbol.

li.p: The schematic diagrams within scope are:

ul.li: process flow diagram;
piping and instrumentation diagram;
logic diagram;
instrument loop diagram.

li.p: a reference data library of classes:
The classes within scope specify the nature of the following:

ul.li: an individual physical object;
an indvidual activity;
an individual document, organisation or person;
a composition or connection relationship between physical objects or activities;
a property of a physical object or activity;
the involvement of a physical object, document, organisation or person in an activity.

note.p: This part of ISO 10303 can be used to store a reference data library of classes. Data conforming to this part of ISO 10303 can reference a library of classes. The referenced library of classes can be stored in the format defined by this part of ISO 10303 or any other format which gives each class within the library a unique identifier.

li.p: Data conforming to this part of ISO 10303 can make reference to the reference data library defined by ISO 10303-4. Data conforming to this part of ISO 10303 can also reference a library of standard parts conforming to ISO 13584.
a person and organisation and information about a person and organisation.

example.p: Information about a person or organisation includes:

ul.li: identification;
employment relationships;
classification;
the involvment of a person or organisation in an activity.

li.p: conceptual process design, using process simulators;
simulation or functional testing of systems;
3D shape representation of the plant items, and their spatial configuration in a 3D model;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-227.

li.p: detailed building automation installation information;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-212 and ISO 10303-225.

li.p: detailed physical design of process controls and monitoring systems and of electrotechnical systems;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-212. However, the conceptual functional and physical design of process controls and monitoring systems and of electrotechnical systems is also in the scope of this part of ISO 10303.

li.p: management and cost information related to procurement and construction;
information related to plant operations and maintenance.

description.p: This overview shows the principal break down of the data into:

ul.li: information about individual products and classes of product;
information about individual activities and classes of activity
information about individual people and organizations and classes of people and organization;
properties of individual products and activities and classes of product and activity;
the presentation of individual products and activity, classes of product and activity, and the relationships between them as an intelligent schematic drawing.

description.p: ISO 10303-1156 specifies an application module for the recording of physical items or products within a process plant. Physical items within the scope of this module are as follows:

li.p: material objects within a process plant;

These include physical assets ranging from major items such as vessel, pumps, pipes and valves to small components within assemblies. The major items will usually have unique asset identifiers, but the small items may not.
functional objects within a process plant;

These include physical objects that are defined by their role, rather than their material realisation. Such functional objects are usually identified by a tag rather than by an asset identifier. These tags may be assigned at an early stage in the design process before any material implementation exists.

Operational activities can be concerned only with the functional objects. For example, the pump with tag P_101 may be operated on Friday and again on Monday, even though the asset that performs the role has been changed over the weekend. To support operational views, it is possible to record both:

ul.li: the functional object with its tag, which persists for long periods during the life of the plant; and
the material object with its asset identifier, which is installed to implement the functional object.

description.p: This module supports the recording of classes of physical item, and the classification of individual physical items. Most of the classes are equally valid for material and functional objects within a process plant. For example, either a functional item with a tag, or a material item with an asset identifier can be classified as a centrifugal pump.
This module supports the recording of composition and connectivity. An individual physical item can be broken down into interconnected sub-assemblies and sub-sub-assemblies as required.

ISO 10303-1169 specifies an application module for the recording of processes or activities carried out by people or equipment within a process plant. The things involved in aan activity, and the role that they play can be specified. A thing involved in an activity can be:

ul.li: an input or output batch of process material;
an equipment item that performs an activity; or
a person or organisation that performs an activity.

description.p: This module supports the recording of classes of activity, and the classification of individual activities. A 'role' is a class of involvement and is defined for a class of activity.

This module supports the recording of composition and connectivity. An individual activity can be broken down into interconnected sub-activities and sub-sub-activities as required. A connection between activities implies a flow of something between them. This can be a flow of process material, energy or information.
ISO 10303-1198 specifies an application module for the recording of properties of physical items and activities. A property can be:

li.p: something that is possessed by an individual product or activity;
This is a classification of the individual product or activity.
something that is necessarily possessed by each member of a class of product or activity.
This is a subclass relationship for the class of product or activity.

description.p: ISO 10303-1203 specifies an application module for the recording of schematic drawing, and for linking the symbols on a schematic drawing to the objects they stand for.

ul.li: P&ID (Piping and Instrumentation Diagram): In a schematic of this type, most symbols stand for physical items. Line symbols usually stand for pipes or cables. These physical items can be either functional objects with tags or material objects with asset identifiers.

PFD (Process Flow Diagram): In a schematic of this type, most symbols stand for processes. Line symbols usually stand for flows between processes. A process is often identified by the tag of the functional object that performs it.

description.p: This module supports the recording of libraries of standard symbols, and the classes of plant item or activity for which a standard symbol might stand.

For various reasons, some entities may not be completely exported into an exchange structure. There may be mandatory information in the AIM that has no correspondence in the ARM. Sometimes an application may not maintain all the information that is anticipated for the data exchange. Other times, the information may be maintained by a sending system but not included in the data exchange. Nevertheless, the preprocessor must provide values for all mandatory attributes in an exchange file.
When no data is provided by a sending system for a string value, the preprocessor shall use '/NULL' or the empty string ''.
To further indicate the reason why no data is provided, the following convention shall be used:

ul.li: empty string '' indicates user data managed by the sending system but not provided for data exchange;
$ is used in the physical file, if an optional attribute is not instantiated.

description.p: If the implementation method is ISO 10303-21, the file format shall be encoded according to the syntax and EXPRESS language mapping defined in ISO 10303-21 and to the MIM schema referenced in of this part of ISO 10303.
